articles.headline: E.P.A. Won’t Ease Ethanol Requirements in Gas
articles.snippet: The agency denied a request to cut the quota for the use of ethanol in cars, concluding that the goal of reducing the nation’s reliance on oil trumps any effect on food prices.
articles.abstract: The agency denied a request to cut the quota for the use of ethanol in cars, concluding that the goal of reducing the nation’s reliance on oil trumps any effect on food prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency rejected on Thursday a request to cut the quota for the use of ethanol in cars, concluding, for the time being, that the goal of reducing the nation’s reliance on oil trumps any effect on food prices from making fuel from corn.

articles.headline: Study Finds Settling Is Better Than Going to Trial
articles.snippet: A study of civil lawsuits has found that most of the plaintiffs who decided to pass up a settlement offer and went to trial ended up getting less money.
articles.abstract: A study of civil lawsuits has found that most of the plaintiffs who decided to pass up a settlement offer and went to trial ended up getting less money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Note to victims of accidents, medical malpractice, broken contracts and the like: When you sue, make a deal.

articles.headline: Britain Comes to Grips With a Slowdown
articles.snippet: Britons have come to the realization that after 17 years of uninterrupted growth, the country’s economy is moving closer to recession, and may already be in one.
articles.abstract: Britons have come to the realization that after 17 years of uninterrupted growth, the country’s economy is moving closer to recession, and may already be in one.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England  Down the road from the train station here sits a gaping hole. It was supposed to be one of the tallest and most stylish apartment buildings in Western Europe, complete with interiors designed by Philippe Starck.

articles.headline: Reasons Some Firms Left the U.S.
articles.snippet: It has become received wisdom on Wall Street that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act has damaged American competitiveness. But do the facts support that wisdom?
articles.abstract: It has become received wisdom on Wall Street that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act has damaged American competitiveness. But do the facts support that wisdom?
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become received wisdom on Wall Street that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act has damaged American competitiveness. It made listing in the American market less attractive to foreign companies and drove initial public offerings overseas. It raised costs for American companies without providing any significant benefit.

articles.headline: 2 Banks Buying Back $17 Billion in Securities
articles.snippet: Two major Wall Street firms offered to buy back more than $17 billion of troubled auction-rate securities that they had marketed as being as safe and liquid as cash.
articles.abstract: Two major Wall Street firms offered to buy back more than $17 billion of troubled auction-rate securities that they had marketed as being as safe and liquid as cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two major Wall Street firms on Thursday offered to buy back more than $17 billion of troubled auction-rate securities that they had marketed as being as safe and liquid as cash, moving quickly to contain the legal fallout from the credit crisis.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: Signs Point to a Slower Sales Season for Retailers
articles.snippet: Americans sought out more bargains and cheaper goods in July, leaving the nation’s retailers bracing for a painful back-to-school shopping season.
articles.abstract: Americans sought out more bargains and cheaper goods in July, leaving the nation’s retailers bracing for a painful back-to-school shopping season.
articles.lead_paragraph: With belts firmly tightened, Americans sought out more bargains and cheaper goods in July, leaving the nation’s retailers bracing for a painful back-to-school shopping season.

articles.headline: Gates Pushing Plan for Afghan Army
articles.snippet: A $20 billion plan would aid the Afghan Army and restructure the military command of U.S. and NATO forces in response to a growing Taliban threat.
articles.abstract: A $20 billion plan would aid the Afghan Army and restructure the military command of U.S. and NATO forces in response to a growing Taliban threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will endorse a $20 billion plan to substantially increase the size of Afghanistan’s army and will also restructure the military command of American and NATO forces in response to the growing Taliban threat, senior Pentagon and military officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: Pawlenty Looks to National Stage
articles.snippet: Gov. Tim Pawlenty, seen as an everyman, is among the least-known of John McCain’s vice-presidential prospects.
articles.abstract: Gov. Tim Pawlenty, seen as an everyman, is among the least-known of John McCain’s vice-presidential prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — As is his way, Gov. Tim Pawlenty made a self-deprecating aside on a local radio show this spring during the ceremonial start of the state’s beloved fishing season. He praised his wife’s willingness to fish with him and to watch hockey games, then added, “And I jokingly say, ‘Now, if I could only get her to have sex with me.’ ”

articles.headline: Can the New Rich Buy Respect? One Ukrainian Oligarch Is Trying
articles.snippet: The worldwide boom in commodities has created a growing number of billionaires who are hungry for art, access and, ultimately, acceptance.
articles.abstract: The worldwide boom in commodities has created a growing number of billionaires who are hungry for art, access and, ultimately, acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine  There comes a time in the life of an oligarch when spending money becomes more important than making it. And for Victor Pinchuk, the controversial oligarch and Ukraine’s second-richest man after Rinat Akhmetov, that time is now.

articles.headline: Russia and Georgia Clash Over Separatist Region
articles.snippet: Russia conducted airstrikes on Georgian targets, escalating the conflict in an area of Georgia that is shaping into a test of the power and military reach of an emboldened Kremlin.
articles.abstract: Russia conducted airstrikes on Georgian targets, escalating the conflict in an area of Georgia that is shaping into a test of the power and military reach of an emboldened Kremlin.
articles.lead_paragraph: GORI, Georgia  Russia conducted airstrikes on Georgian targets on Friday evening, escalating the conflict in a separatist area of Georgia that is shaping into a test of the power and military reach of an emboldened Kremlin. Earlier in the day, Russian troops and armored vehicles had rolled into South Ossetia, supporting the breakaway region in its bitter conflict with Georgia.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Anne Barnard and C. J. Chivers

articles.headline: Shares Rally as Oil Continues to Fall
articles.snippet: A day after Wall Street shares dropped sharply, the Dow gained more than 300 points, and the impetus appeared to be a big drop in commodity prices.
articles.abstract: A day after Wall Street shares dropped sharply, the Dow gained more than 300 points, and the impetus appeared to be a big drop in commodity prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what has become a familiar pattern on Wall Street, stocks surged Friday, a day after falling sharply.
